key_points: Google and Facebook threaten to limit services in Australia if a digital news code requiring payment to news media goes ahead.
19 million Australian Google users and 17 million Australian Facebook users would be affected.
The digital news code is designed to support news media by requiring payments from digital platforms for content.
Mel Silva, Google's Australian managing director, described the code as untenable and a potential 'dangerous precedent'.
Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison insists Australia makes its own rules and won't respond to threats.
Reset Australia criticizes Google for behaving like a 'bully' towards the nation.
Facebook's Josh Machin claimed limiting news content would not significantly affect the platform since news makes up less than 5% of what users see.
Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) chair, Rod Sims, emphasizes that the code promotes fairness in negotiations between digital platforms and news media.
Labor's shadow communications minister, Michelle Rowland, expresses concern over the impracticability of the code.
A poll found a majority of Australians support prioritizing journalism in social media feeds and transparency about algorithm influences.
spokespersons: Josh Machin (Head of Public Policy, Facebook Australia)
Rod Sims (Chair, Australian Competition and Consumer Commission)
